result.markdown:
--- title: "Hands-on Exercise 4b: Visualising Uncertainty" author: "Ho Zi Jun" date: "May 04, 2024" date-modified: "last-modified" execute: eval: true echo: true warning: false freeze: true --- ## [11.1]{style="color:grey"} Learning Outcomes Visualising uncertainty is relatively new in statistical graphics. In this chapter, we will gain hands-on experience in creating statistical graphics for visualising uncertainty. By the end of this chapter we will be able: - to plot statistics error bars by using ggplot2, - to plot interactive error bars by combining ggplot2, plotly and DT, - to create advanced by using ggdist, and - to create hypothetical outcome plots (HOPs) by using ungeviz package. ## [11.2]{style="color:grey"} Getting Started ### [11.2.1]{style="color:grey"} Installing and loading the packages For the purpose of this exercise, the following R packages will be used, they are: - `tidyverse`, a family of R packages for data science process, - `plotly` for creating interactive plot, - `gganimate` for creating animation plot, - `DT` for displaying interactive html table, - `crosstalk` for for implementing cross-widget interactions (currently, linked brushing and filtering), and - `ggdist` for visualising distribution and uncertainty, - `ggridges`a ggplot2 extension specially designed for plotting ridgeline plots, - `colorspace` an R package which provides a broad toolbox for selecting individual colors or color palettes, - `unigeviz` provides add-on functionality for ggplot2 to make it easier to visualize uncertainty ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} devtools::install_github("wilkelab/ungeviz") ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(ungeviz, plotly, crosstalk, DT, ggdist, ggridges, colorspace, gganimate, tidyverse, dplyr) ``` ::: ### [11.2.2]{style="color:grey"} Data Import For the purpose of this exercise, Exam_data.csv will be used. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exam <- read.csv("data/Exam_data.csv") ``` ::: ## [11.3]{style="color:grey"} Visualizing the uncertainty of point estimates: ggplot2 methods A point estimate is a single number, such as a mean. Uncertainty, on the other hand, is expressed as standard error, confidence interval, or credible interval. ::: callout-Important - Don’t confuse the [uncertainty]{.underline} of a point estimate with the [variation]{.underline} in the sample ::: In this section, we will learn how to plot error bars of maths scores by race by using data provided in exam tibble data frame. Firstly, code chunk below will be used to derive the necessary summary statistics. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} my_sum <- exam %>% group_by(RACE) %>% summarise( n = n(), mean = mean(MATHS), sd = sd(MATHS) ) %>% mutate(se = sd/sqrt(n-1)) ``` ::: ::: callout-tip ## Things to learn from the code chunk above - `group_by()` of dplyr package is used to group the observation by RACE, - `summarise()` is used to compute the count of observations, mean, standard deviation - `mutate()` is used to derive standard error of Maths by RACE, and - the output is save as a tibble data table called my_sum. ::: ::: callout-note For the mathematical explanation, please refer to [Slide 20 of Lesson 4](https://isss608-ay2023-24apr.netlify.app/lesson/lesson04/lesson04-fundamentals%20of%20visual%20analytics#/18). ::: Next, the code chunk below will be used to display *my_sum* tibble data frame in an html table format. ::: panel-tabset ## The code chunk ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} knitr::kable(head(my_sum), format = 'html') ``` ::: ## The table ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
RACE n mean sd se
Chinese 193 76.50777 15.69040 1.132357
Indian 12 60.66667 23.35237 7.041005
Malay 108 57.44444 21.13478 2.043177
Others 9 69.66667 10.72381 3.791438
````` ::: ::: ::: ### [11.3.1]{style="color:grey"} Plotting standard error bars of point estimates Now we are ready to plot the standard error bars of mean maths score by race as shown below. ::: panel-tabset ## The plot ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04b_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## The code chunk ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(my_sum) + geom_errorbar( aes(x=RACE, ymin=mean-se, ymax=mean+se), width=0.2, colour="black", alpha=0.9, size=0.5) + geom_point(aes (x=RACE, y=mean), stat="identity", colour="red", size=1.5, alpha=1) + ggtitle("Standard error of mean Maths score by Race") ``` ::: ::: callout-tip ## Things to learn from the code chunk above - The error bars are computed by using the formula mean+/-se. - For `geom_point()`, it is important to indicate stat=“identity”. ::: ::: ### [11.3.2]{style="color:grey"} Plotting confidence interval of point estimates Instead of plotting the standard error bar of point estimates, we can also plot the confidence intervals of mean maths score by race. ::: panel-tabset ## The plot ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04b_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## The code chunk ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(my_sum) + geom_errorbar( aes(x=reorder(RACE, -mean), ymin=mean-1.96*se, ymax=mean+1.96*se), width=0.2, colour="black", alpha=0.9, size=0.5) + geom_point(aes (x=RACE, y=mean), stat="identity", colour="red", size=1.5, alpha=1) + labs(x = "Maths score", title = "95% Confidence Interval of mean Maths score by Race") ``` ::: ::: callout-tip ## Things to learn from the code chunk above - The confidence intervals are computed by using the formula mean+/-1.96\*se. - The error bars are sorted by using the average maths scores. - `labs()` argument of ggplot2 is used to change the x-axis label. ::: ::: ### [11.3.3]{style="color:grey"} Visualizing the uncertainty of point estimates with interactive error bars In this section, we will learn how to plot interactive error bars for the 99% confidence interval of mean maths score by race as shown in the figure below. ::: panel-tabset ## The plot ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## The code chunk ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} shared_df = SharedData$new(my_sum) bscols(widths = c(4,8), ggplotly((ggplot(shared_df) + geom_errorbar(aes( x=reorder(RACE, -mean), ymin=mean-2.58*se, ymax=mean+2.58*se), width=0.2, colour="black", alpha=0.9, size=0.5) + geom_point(aes( x=RACE, y=mean, text = paste("Race:", `RACE`, "
N:", `n`, "
Avg.Scores:", round(mean, digits = 2), "
95% CI: [", round((mean-2.58*se), digits = 2), ",", round((mean+2.58*se), digits = 2),"]")), stat="identity", colour="red", size = 1.5, alpha=1) + xlab("Race") + ylab("Average Scores") + theme_minimal() + theme(axis.text.x = element_text( angle = 45, vjust = 0.5, hjust = 1)) + ggtitle("99% Confidence Interval of average /
Maths scores by Race")), tooltip = "text"), DT::datatable(shared_df, rownames = FALSE, class = "compact", width = "100%", options = list(pageLength = 10, scrollX = T), colnames = c("No. of pupils", "Avg Scores", "Std Dev", "Std Error")) %>% formatRound(columns = c('mean', 'sd', 'se'), digits = 2)) ``` ::: ::: ## [11.4]{style="color:grey"} Visualising Uncertainty: **ggdist** package - [**ggdist**](https://mjskay.github.io/ggdist/) is a R package that provides a flexible set of ggplot2 geoms and stats designed especially for visualising distributions and uncertainty. - It is designed for both frequentist and Bayesian uncertainty visualization, taking the view that uncertainty visualization can be unified through the perspective of distribution visualization: - for frequentist models, one visualises confidence distributions or bootstrap distributions (see vignette(“freq-uncertainty-vis”)); - for Bayesian models, one visualises probability distributions (see the [**tidybayes**](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/tidybayes/index.html) package, which builds on top of ggdist). ![](ggdist.png) ### [11.4.1]{style="color:grey"} Visualizing the uncertainty of point estimates: ggdist methods In the code chunk below,[`stat_pointinterval()`](https://mjskay.github.io/ggdist/reference/stat_pointinterval.html) of **ggdist** is used to build a visual for displaying distribution of maths scores by race. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exam %>% ggplot(aes(x = RACE, y= MATHS)) + stat_pointinterval() + labs( title = "Visualising Confidence Intervals of mean Maths score", subtitle = "Mean Point + Multiple-interval plot") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04b_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: callout-Note This function comes with many arguments, students are advised to read the syntax reference for more detail. ::: For example, in the code chunk below the following arguments are used: - .width = 0.95 - .point = median - .interval = qi ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exam%>% ggplot(aes(x = RACE, y = MATHS)) + stat_pointinterval(.width = 0.95, .point = median, .interval = qi) + labs( title = "Visualising Confidence Intervals of Median Math score", subtitle = "Median Point + Multiple-interval plot" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04b_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### [11.4.2]{style="color:grey"} Visualizing the uncertainty of point estimates: ggdist methods ::: callout-note ## Try it yourself Makeover the plot on previous slide by showing 95% and 99% confidence intervals. ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exam %>% ggplot(aes(x = RACE, y = MATHS)) + stat_pointinterval( show.legend = FALSE) + labs( title = "Visualising confidence intervals of mean math score", subtitle = "Mean Point + Multiple-interval plot") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04b_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: panel-tabset ## The plot (95 % CI) ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04b_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## The plot (99% CI) ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-on_Ex04b_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## The code chunk ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} exam %>% ggplot(aes(x = RACE, y = MATHS)) + stat_pointinterval(.width = 0.95) + labs( title = "Visualising 95% confidence intervals of mean math score", subtitle = "Mean Point + Multiple-interval plot") exam %>% ggplot(aes(x = RACE, y = MATHS)) + stat_pointinterval(.width = 0.99) + labs( title = "Visualising 99% confidence intervals of mean math score", subtitle = "Mean Point + Multiple-interval plot") ``` ::: ::: ## [11.5]{style="color:grey"} Visualising Uncertainty with Hypothetical Outcome Plots (HOPs) 1.0 ## [11.6]{style="color:grey"} Visualising Uncertainty with Hypothetical Outcome Plots (HOPs) 2.0
